message: And my .vimrc file is getting loaded -- all of my extensions are available.  Just for some reason colorscheme is botched.
hmm... that's different than set syntax=on?
It seems to be taking the colorscheme from the iTerm instance its in rather than using what's defined in my .vimrc
I'm not seeing any errors when it loads

did you try
:syntax on
That works (whereas :set syntax=on doesn't), but it doesn't grab the correct colorscheme, nor does the :colorscheme jellybean turn it on :-/
just another notation, so no solution for your problem...
I'm having issues - syntax highlighting and such all work great inside MacVim, but not when I open the include Vim version of the command-line tool.  Any ideas?

your theme is going to look different in console than it does in MacVim unless you set your terminal to xterm-256color. If you get an error about the term database after setting the term variable and trying to clear the screen then you need to install ncurses from macports to get the correct terminal definition.
I've tried manually setting `rtp` via --cmd then sourcing my .vimrc, but that doesn't work either.  Says it can't find pathogen before having a bunch of errors.
Hmm... so setting TERM, then launching gets me close, but syntax highlighting isn't on.  Found the issue for that -- my .vimrc doesn't have `syntax on` in it.
@kennyparnell That was the missing piece.  Thanks!
Well, it gets me part of the way there at least...
For some reason it's not loading my ~/.vimrc and ~/.vim/* files
@davidblewett Thanks for the link, though.  Gave me the idea of doing <leader>s for spell check which gets me what I need to use it at the command line.
Still having an issue with things not getting loaded, however.  For example, in MacVim the python strings are not spellchecked, but they are in terminal vim.
Just an idea, but one of my co-workers keeps his dotfiles on github: https://github.com/claytron/dotfiles . We all use similar versions, and everything works fine on the CLI in OS X, FreeBSD.
@davidblewett My .vim files are on GH as well: https://github.com/tswicegood/my.vim

@tswicegood can you post the output of :version for your console vim? Also, if you want to use the same vim binary as MacVim and you have the mvim command installed you can alias vim='mvim -v' in your shell.
Yup - I've aliased vi/vim to /Applications/MacVim/Contents/MacOS/Vim (it's the command line version).
